sub_title: Sr. Director, Climate Projects Design, Management & Evaluation (PDME) at South Pole
summary:
I’m a sustainability/climate change expert and social entrepreneur. Right now leading a global team at South Pole conducting project development, implementation and project management services in the field of climate change mitigation i.e. sustainable technologies & nature based solutions, AFOLU.

The tasks include overall supervision on project development as well as strategic thinking and decision making on team management, QA/QC and workflow/process optimisation within the unit. The above is achieved in collaboration/coordination with the portfolio, operations, global sourcing & climate policy teams. 

The int’l award winner (2011-2021 Environmental Finance) project development and implementation (PDI) unit - with +200 highly skilled experts - is in charge of an effective and smooth supply process within the climate mitigation action chain. The team is amongst the best and can effectively handle diverse, complex and multidisciplinary topics with high quality and innovative approach. The processes within the unit are designed, and constantly improving, to smoothly and transparently identify, develop, quantify and verify a variety of environmental products e.g. CO2 emission reductions (ER) credits, renewable energy certificates (REC) and sustainable development goals (SDG) under various schemes e.g. UNFCCC, Verra (aka VCS), Gold Standard (GS4GG), Social Carbon (SC), Climate, Community and Biodiversity Standard (CCBS), ISO mitigation claims/certificates, Women and Gender Standard (W+) etc. 

Our risk assessment and management (RAM) tool together with our systematic QA/QC and M&E processes insures high quality projects with long term socio-ecological safeguarding mechanism in place. 

Example of products and services: initial project assessment (IPA), full due diligence, project design document (PDD) development, methodology design and (digital) monitoring, reporting and verification (MRV) planning as well as validation/registration and verification/issuance, ground implementation services, monitoring & evaluation reporting (M&E).

Example of climate project scopes: Renewable energy, energy efficiency, waste/water management, biofuel/biogas/biomass, green urban development, transport, CCSU, hydrogen, community-based projects (e.g. cookstoves, domestic biogas, water purification, solar home systems), Nature Based Solutions (NBS) / AFOLU i.e. Afforestation & Reforestation, REDD+, Blue Carbon, Land Use, Agriculture, Biodiversity and Communities.

profile_positions.description:
The Climate Projects Design, Management & Evaluation (PDME) practice within the Climate Projects unit is established to constantly review, design and maintain the most pragmatic and optimised processes and tools for climate projects management cycle, from initiation to long term operation. The objective is to support the global project teams to reach their targets in a smooth, effective and high quality manner. Above support is also backed by our (digital) data science policy throughout our internal and external processes and deliverables, led by the Digital Innovation team.

The unit is structured to facilitate strategic support to projects teams and other practices within the CP unit. This structure includes practices such as the Quality Assurance & Quality Control (QA/QC), Digital Innovation, Nature Based Solutions scopes, Sustainable Technology scopes, Implementation and M&E affairs and Standards & Methodologies. 

PDME together with the Technology Strategy as two global functions of the Climate Projects unit lead the process of coordinating and channeling our harmonised project strategy, quality, knowledge and IP in support of our global climate project objectives.

profile_positions.description:
The project development & implementation unit is responsible for climate mitigation project identification, assessment, development/implementation and ground management; overseeing the generation of environmental assets incl. carbon credits and renewable energy certificates globally. The role includes strategical and technical support to the global sourcing team for the voluntary and compliance markets. The work covers a wide range of tasks and coordinates the supply side of South Pole's (SP) global portfolio.

South Pole is a global sustainability solutions provider with operations in over 25 offices and +800 professionals around the globe. We’ve been proud to work with a wide range of multilateral, NGOs, public/private/civil organisations for over a decade. Our expertise and services cover a wide range of multidisciplinary topics around project and technology finance, data/advisory and high tech GIS and MRV services as well as risk assessment/management and QC/QA tools. 

South Pole has advised, developed and managed over 800 climate mitigation projects generating varieties of products including greenhouse gas (GHG) emission reduction (carbon) credits. These comprise technologies such as renewable energy, energy efficiency, waste management and sustainable technologies or nature based solutions (NBS) and forestry and land-use (AFOLU) climate mitigation, community and biodiversity based projects as offsetting and/or insetting schemes globally. 

South Pole is committed to, and in the forefront of, leading the climate mitigation policies, actions and market developments towards below 1.5C targets, in line with the Paris goals and post-Paris implementation era. South Pole is actively involved in the process of interpretation, planning and implementation of projects with the use of varieties of new mechanisms under Article 6, including voluntary sector contributions.

profile_positions.description:
Dasht Foundation was established in 2017 by climate scientists and sustainability experts. The mission is to eliminate financial hurdles as well as negative environmental and social impacts in agricultural and other land/nature use activities. Dasht aims to accomplish this by increasing awareness and knowledge among local communities/farmers and NGOs and by inspiring them with innovative, pragmatic and sustainable solutions. 

Dasht aims at bringing capacity and knowledge/awareness to farmers and alert them on the dangers of non-planned, environmental unfriendly and cost/effort intensive manners, that how they can become resilient and mitigate the impacts of climate change. We strive to showcase to communities, by piloting small scale projects, on how to save their land and other vital natural resources by implementing sustainable farming practices and measures that are also financially sustainable at the same time. The goal is to make farmers aware how to modify their planning and implementation for efficient use of resources and other needs. 

In order to achieve the above, Dasht facilitates knowledge transfer in support of the organic farming and circularity movements around the globe. Dasht's local offices provide a direct point of contact and offer advisory, project engagement and management services as well as  monitoring and follow up service as required.

profile_positions.description:
The Technical Working Group of the Initiative for Climate Action Transparency (ICAT) provides expert input on ICAT's methodological framework. The framework will help countries transparently measure and assess the impacts of climate policies and actions. Input of Working Group members are sought on guidance across sectors such as, Greenhouse Gas (GHG) mitigation in energy, transport, agriculture and forestry sectors; sustainable development; transformational change; stakeholder participation; verification; financing and non-state actions.

About ICAT initiative:
The Initiative was founded by the German Federal Ministry for the Environment, Nature Conservation, Building and Nuclear Safety (BMUB), the Children’s Investment Fund Foundation (CIFF), the Italian Ministry of the Environment (EMELS) and the ClimateWorks Foundation. The main objective is to prepare a methodological framework through which countries transparently measure and assess the impacts of climate policies and actions. The United Nations Office for Project Services (UNOPS) manages the trust fund through which the Initiative is funded. This structure allows new donors to join the trust fund. The implementing partners are UNEP DTU Partnership (UDP), Verified Carbon Standard (VCS) and World Resources Institute (WRI). The Climate, Community & Biodiversity Alliance (CCBA) and Rainforest Alliance are supporting partners and will contribute to specific aspects of the Initiative.

profile_positions.description:
Foundation Rural Energy Services (FRES) advances rural electrification in developing countries by setting up small-scale commercial electricity companies in off-grid areas. FRES offers households and small local businesses access to affordable, reliable and sustainable energy (e.g. derived from solar energy). FRES Netherlands provides the expertise and investments needed for the FRES businesses to start up, grow, and most importantly, become self-reliant.  Currently there are five FRES companies in Mali, South Africa. Burkina Faso, Uganda and Guinea Bissau. A new FRES company will be established in Cameroon in 2016.

The majority of 1.2 billion people who have zero access to electricity are in about a dozen countries in Africa and Asia. Energy is central to nearly every major challenge and opportunity the world faces today such as jobs, security, climate change, food production or increasing incomes. Sustainable energy is opportunity as it transforms lives, economies and the planet. On 1 January 2016, the 17 Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs) of the 2030 Agenda for Sustainable Development — adopted by world leaders in September 2015 at an historic UN Summit — officially came into force. Out of 17 SDGs, goal 7 is to ensure access to affordable, reliable, sustainable and modern energy for all, something that FRES strives to achieve daily.
